0.68.text: I'd just been on a month-long holiday.

8.16.text:
He ran his finger around a dark blur on an
ultrasound scan.

14.44.text:
Then he said the scariest words I have ever
heard.

18.52.text: This is typical of a large cancer mass.

48.65.text: Are you a man with prostate cancer?

69.99.text:
Do you want to understand your disease so
you can talk sensibly to your doctors?

75.78.text: You're in the right place - so am I.

80.48.text:
I'm just a man with locally advanced prostate
cancer.

86.18.text:
One of the things the doctor said was Stage
T3 something, something.

92.45.text: Was this stage number another measure of aggressiveness like Gleason score?

96.60.text: I cover Gleason score in another video.

99.48.text:
I came to understand the T3 thing was about
prostate cancer staging - particularly TNM

111.03.text: An explanation of TNM staging is fairly simple.

114.99.text:
But it helps to know a little basic anatomy,
which not all my audience may know.

120.07.text:
So, a few quiz questions, after the fashion
of the TV show Qi.

125.32.text:
Ok, contestants, hands on buzzers, no conferring,
no saying the answer out loud.

134.49.text:
Your probably know that the heart pumps the
blood around the body.

139.67.text:
An easy question to see first if you know
simple terms.

144.53.text:
All the FRESH blood flows FROM the heart through
the arteries.

148.99.text:
All the USED blood flows TO the heart through
the veins.

164.46.text:
If you said TRUE, stand up and take a bow.
Now!

172.45.text:
If you took a bow, I guess you don't watch
QI.

174.55.text:
QI is full of tricky questions where the answer
most people would give is wrong.

179.61.text: The screen flashes black, and a klaxon sounds.

191.05.text: The reason you were wrong was that I said

195.50.text:
Not ALL the used blood flows back through
the veins -

198.68.text:
which will become clearer when you answer
the next question:

202.53.text:
Ok, contestants, hands on buzzers, no conferring,
no saying the answer out loud.

208.59.text:
During the time it takes for the 5 litres
of blood in your body to circulate around

214.59.text:
your body, about 10% of is extracted as a
clear-ish fluid and takes a different path.

223.33.text:
I'll take a medical term, or a less polite
term as an answer.

237.94.text:
If your answer was urine, or pee, or piss.
Stand up and take a bow

250.84.text:
That 5 or so litres of blood circulates around
your body in around one minute.

257.75.text:
I'm afraid that if 10% of your blood every
minute was destined for the toilet,

262.72.text:
very simple maths shows you would last no
longer than 10 minutes!

268.37.text:
The medical term for the clear-ish fluid from
your blood that does not flow back to your

273.89.text: heart through your veins is LYMPH.

277.23.text: I don't know any less polite terms.

279.63.text:
So, roughly speaking, your heart pumps 100%
of your fresh blood through your arteries

288.28.text: and 90% of your used blood through your veins.

291.99.text:
10% of your used blood travels back to the
heart through your lymphatic system.

299.22.text:
Ok, contestants, hands on buzzers, no conferring,
no saying the answer out loud.

307.59.text:
What moves the lymph through the lymphatic
system back to the heart:

315.18.text:
Skeletal muscles such as the muscles that
move your arms and legs?

320.84.text:
Smooth muscles similar to the muscles that
move food through your bowels along the lymphatic

328.88.text: Muscles that you use to breathe?

330.86.text:
A series of one-way valves inside the lymphatic
tubes?

358.50.text:
Here we can see a section of the tube that
the lymph flows along, a lymph vessel.

363.99.text:
That green blob in the lymph vessel is lymph
which will travel up the vessel.

370.98.text: The pairs of blue lines are one-way valves.

374.38.text: Here they are closed as they normally are.

377.47.text:
The red ovals either side of the tube are
muscles.

381.14.text:
When these muscles contract they will push
the lymph against the one-way valves.

389.61.text:
The valves only work one way, so the bottom
valve stays shut, while the top valve opens

396.93.text:
When the muscles relax again, as here, the
lymph is on its way.

403.75.text:
So, when you squash a lymphatic tube, the
lymph can only flow towards the heart.

409.92.text: And what can squash a lymphatic tube?

412.51.text:
Your skeletal muscles like those in your arms
and legs.

416.65.text: Your breathing muscles that move your diaphragm.

420.90.text:
Some special smooth muscles that just work
on the lymphatic tubes.

426.14.text:
So for full points, you had to choose all
four of answers B, C, D, and E.

434.91.text:
One time we notice the lymphatic system is
when it goes wrong.

439.14.text:
If we don't work our skeletal muscles - especially
arms and legs - or our breathing muscles enough,

446.28.text:
the lymph cannot flow back, and collects,
especially in low places.

451.64.text:
So, if you spend time as a couch potato, or
trapped in an aircraft seat for a long time,

458.98.text:
you may notice the lymph collecting around
your feet and ankles, making them swell.

466.97.text:
Another time we notice the lymphatic system
is when it is going right - when it is doing

473.98.text: Which brings us to our next question:

476.74.text:
Ok, hands on buzzers, no conferring, no saying
the answer out loud.

481.97.text:
I went to the doctor recently and reported
feeling a little off colour.

487.55.text:
The doctor put his hands on me something like
this.

491.99.text: What was the doctor looking for?

509.14.text:
Five points if your answer had LYMPH NODES
in it.

512.41.text:
Ten points if your answer had SWOLLEN LYMPH
NODES in it.

517.10.text:
In around 100 places around your body there
is a bulge in the lymph vessel called a lymph

523.61.text:
One of the jobs of a lymph node is to help
the immune system to handle infection.

529.26.text: As it fights infection it temporarily swells.

533.76.text:
Many lymph nodes are hidden well inside your
body.

536.81.text:
But some, like those in your neck, under your
armpit, or in your groin are close enough

547.49.text:
If the doctor feels the lymph nodes HERE are
swollen, he or she will perhaps be looking

560.35.text:
In a few places in the body there are bunches
of lymph nodes.

565.03.text: I'm in my late sixties as I make this video.

569.04.text:
I'll be in my early seventies when you are
watching it.

572.84.text:
Ok, contestants, hands on buzzers, no conferring,
no saying the answer out loud.

578.57.text:
I've lost a couple of bunches of lymph nodes.
What is the most likely cause?

596.16.text:
If you said cancer, stand up and take a bow
...

607.06.text:
Certainly if you've had surgery for cancer,
you may have lost some lymph nodes at that

612.68.text:
But take yourself a full 10 points if you
said Tonsils.

618.03.text:
The two bunches of lymph nodes either side
of the throat are called the tonsils.

623.21.text:
Chronic infection of the tonsils is sometimes
today dealt with by surgical removal.

629.79.text:
But when people my age were younger tonsil
removal was much more common,

634.47.text:
and that's the most likely reason people my
age have lost bunches of lymph nodes.

643.19.text: Enough of the QI type questions for now.

646.46.text:
Back to the topic of cancer stage, particularly
the T N M stage.

653.45.text:
No. It's not a measure of aggressiveness - that's
Gleason score, and there's another video on

660.02.text:
I promised you that TNM staging is simple.
Here it is:

666.52.text:
Doctors use the TNM stage to tell where the
cancer is.

673.92.text: Tumor is another name for cancer.

690.56.text:
That's lymph nodes. You should know a bit
about them now.

697.11.text:
Metastases are bits of cancer growing away
from the original site.

701.08.text: Let me show you the TNM stages.

706.13.text: This is my picture of a prostate.

708.33.text: The real thing is probably not so pretty.

710.13.text:
But I am not a doctor, or anything medical,
so I wouldn't know, really.

715.67.text:
The prostate has a sort of skin around it,
called the capsule wall.

718.97.text:
Apparently it is quite thin. But I have made
mine thick and orange so you can see it better.

725.73.text:
The prostate is made of two lumpy bits called
lobes.

729.70.text: I'll just show them with a line down the middle.

734.65.text:
There are important bits around the prostate
and running through it.

737.84.text:
But I like things simple, so the only things
I am going to show are the seminal vesicles.

743.54.text:
I don't know exactly where they attach, or
what they look like,

747.15.text:
so I put them at the top. The seminal vesicles
make part of the fluid for sex.

755.64.text: T for tumour. Tumour is another name for cancer.

759.27.text:
Your T rating tells about the cancer that
started growing in your prostate.

769.16.text: Higher numbers are generally more serious.

774.58.text:
A T1 cancer can't be felt by a doctor, or
seen on a scan.

779.62.text:
So we'll start with T2 cancers. T2 cancers
can be felt by doctors.

788.39.text: The cancer is completely inside the capsule.

791.31.text: The cancer is completely inside one lobe.

795.03.text:
The cancer takes up LESS that half of one
lobe.

798.94.text: This is called a T2a cancer.

805.69.text: The cancer is completely inside the capsule.

808.55.text: The cancer is completely inside one lobe.

811.61.text:
The cancer takes up MORE that half of the
lobe.

815.59.text: This is called a T2b cancer.

821.64.text: The cancer is completely inside the capsule.

824.61.text: The cancer is inside both lobes.

827.62.text: This is called a T2c cancer.

830.91.text: So, the key thing about T2 cancers is that

834.32.text: they are completely contained within the prostate.

838.44.text: T2a - less than half of one lobe

841.41.text: T2b - more than half of one lobe

849.89.text: Now we move to the T3 cancers.

853.04.text:
If the cancer has grown right through the
capsule wall, but not into any other organs

860.48.text: It has to be right through the capsule wall.

863.15.text:
Just growing into the capsule wall itself
is not enough.

866.76.text:
Next, here's where our seminal vesicles come
in.

871.08.text:
If the cancer has grown through the capsule
wall and up into one or both the seminal vesicles,

882.06.text:
The final T rating - T4 comes if the cancer
has grown out of the prostate and into other

889.36.text:
like the bladder or bowel which are both uncomfortably
close by.

900.12.text: T3b - growing into the seminal vesicles

904.00.text: T4 - growing into other nearby organs.

911.12.text:
T2 The cancer is completely contained within
the prostate.

915.75.text:
T3 The cancer has grown through the prostate
wall.

919.92.text:
T4 The cancer has grown through the prostate
wall into vital organs.

926.22.text:
So the T of TNM was about the cancer in your
prostate and how far it grew.

931.18.text:
N and M are about any new cancers it may have
started in other parts of your body.

938.76.text:
N is for Node - lymph nodes - but not all
the lymph nodes.

943.89.text:
For the N rating, doctors are only interested
in the lymph nodes that are near to your prostate.

950.74.text:
If you are close enough to the screen, you
can see some of the lymph nodes around this

957.28.text:
Zero of them have any cancer so he scores
N0.

963.51.text:
This guy is not so lucky. One of the lymph
nodes near to his prostate has cancer.

973.45.text:
Because he has cancer in one or more lymph
nodes NEAR his prostate he scores N1.

987.32.text: One or more nearby lymph nodes N1.

990.73.text:
Finally we move to cancers that have moved
further afield - the M for metastasis score.

999.00.text: First the guy with zero distant cancers.

1005.04.text:
Next a guy who has cancer in a lymph node
NOT near his prostate.

1010.10.text:
He looks to have his cancer spread to near
his arm pit.

1018.13.text: Next a far more common case.

1020.31.text:
If prostate cancer spreads we say metastasises
it prefers bone 90% of the time.

1028.72.text:
If prostate cancer gets to the bone, it scores
M1b.

1033.35.text:
The final M score is for a cancer that is
growing in soft tissue away from the prostate.

1041.27.text:
Looks like this man might have prostate cancer
in the pancreas, spleen, liver ...

1045.67.text: I don't know enough about the body to tell.

1049.19.text:
Anyway - prostate cancer spread to soft tissue
away from the prostate - he scores M1c.

1055.66.text: I should clear up something here.

1058.43.text:
Wherever prostate cancer spreads, it is still
prostate cancer.

1063.20.text:
Prostate cancer in the bone is still prostate
cancer, NOT bone cancer.

1069.17.text:
Under the microscope, your pathologist can
see the difference.

1073.96.text:
Prostate cancer in the liver is still prostate
cancer, NOT liver cancer.

1080.06.text:
Prostate cancer in the lung is still prostate
cancer, NOT lung cancer.

1087.78.text:
So now we have a T rating, an N rating and
an M rating.

1093.30.text:
If a man has cancer growing through the prostate
wall into a seminal vesicle, that's T3b.

1101.78.text:
With no cancer in lymph nodes near the prostate,
that's N0.

1107.02.text:
With no cancers yet found distant from the
prostate that's M0.

1112.43.text:
So thats T3b N0 M0, or T3 for short, or locally
advanced in common language.

1125.02.text:
Just in case there is a newly diagnosed man
with a locally advanced cancer, a T3,

1130.81.text:
listening to this who is wondering whether
he has 2 weeks or 2 months ahead of him,

1135.49.text: it may help him to know this.

1140.54.text:
It filled the right side of my prostate, it
spilled into the left side.

1146.58.text:
It was growing through the wall of the prostate
in two places, including up and around a nearby

1157.54.text:
The Gleason score of six out of six of the
biopsy samples on the right side was 5+4=9.

1168.65.text:
In all a large, locally advanced, aggressive
cancer.

1174.80.text:
As I make this video, that was almost six
years ago, and my PSA is currently undetectable

1185.38.text:
If you are a man with advanced prostate cancer
- locally advanced, like me,

1191.53.text: metastatic, that is spread to other parts,

1193.81.text: or recurrent, returned after your first treatment,

1197.64.text:
there is a group of men helping each other
understand the disease.

1201.50.text:
The Advanced Prostate Cancer Support Group
offers information and online forums at

1215.85.text:
That's the word Jim FOUR times, no spaces,
dot com. Nothing else - just dot com.
